channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Protesters in Kiev Topple Lenin Statue as Rallies Grow
item.description: Protests in Ukraine’s capital, which have grown for two weeks and seemed to reach new heights Sunday, show the depth of rage at Ukraine’s president, who has few palatable options to defuse the country’s crisis.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: A teenager waved a national flag over a crowd of pro-Europe activists gathered at a rally in Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: In an Israeli Plan, Bedouins See a Threat to Their Way of Life
item.description: After decades of discrimination and neglect, many Bedouins and their supporters see, in Israeli offers of jobs, education and homes, a plot to destroy their way of life.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Members of Thai Opposition Party Quit Parliament
item.description: The Democrat Party said its members would join street protests against the government, deepening Thailand’s political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: The opposition leader Abhisit Vejjajiva, sitting, second from left, and fellow party members at a news conference at the Democrat Party headquarters in Bangkok on Sunday.

item.title: Bombings Kill Dozens Around Baghdad
item.description: The attacks in largely Shiite neighborhoods of the Iraqi capital killed at least 45 people and wounded dozens more, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Justice for Abused Afghan Women Still Elusive, U.N. Report Says
item.description: The report, released by the United Nations, said years of intensive efforts by Afghan and international rights advocates have done little to increase prosecutions.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: South Korea Announces Expansion of Its Air Defense Zone
item.description: The move creates a military air patrol region that overlaps with zones declared by Japan and China at a time of heightened tensions over disputed territory in the region.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: South Africans Embark on Day of ‘Prayer and Reflection’ for Mandela
item.description: At the start of a week of commemorations, South Africans gathered Sunday to pay homage to the man who embodied the battle against apartheid.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Women prayed on Sunday at the African Methodist Episcopal Church in the township of Alexandra.

item.title: State Elections Deal Blow to Indian National Congress
item.description: The results signaled the waning power of the dynasty that has dominated Indian politics for nearly all the post-Independence era.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Decades After the Cultural Revolution, a Rare Letter of Remorse
item.description: The son of a famed Chinese official posted a letter apologizing for his role in the abuse of his teachers during the Cultural Revolution.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chen Xiaolu, a former Red Guard leader, sitting at home next to a picture of his father, the Communist war hero Chen Yi.

item.title: In Nation Remade by Mandela, Social Equality Remains Elusive
item.description: Black South Africans are still very far behind whites when it comes to income and education, and by some measures falling further back.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN and MARCUS MABRY
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many black South Africans have made gains, but poverty persists in Soweto and elsewhere.

item.title: Parliament Approves 2014 Budget in Greece
item.description: After several days of debate, the coalition members of Parliament supported a budget that predicts a mild return to growth.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Musicals Couldn’t Be Hotter Off Broadway (by 7,000 Miles)
item.description: Seoul, South Korea, has become a boomtown for American musicals, with producers opening Korean-language versions of hits and flops alike.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK HEALY
item.media:description: Korean actors in the Seoul production of “Wicked.”

item.title: Bedouins Fight to Keep Their Family Land
item.description: Israeli officials have struggled to convince residents that giving up land their families have lived on for generations will lead to a better future.

item.title: Bedouins Fight to Keep Their Family Land
item.description: Israeli officials have struggled to convince residents that giving up land their families have lived on for generations will lead to a better future.

item.title: DealBook: JPMorgan Tabulated Business Linked to China Hiring
item.description: Confidential documents offer the most detailed account yet of JPMorgan Chase’s “Sons and Daughters” hiring program in China, which has been at the center of a federal bribery investigation.
item.dc:creator: By BEN PROTESS and JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG
item.media:description: An office of JPMorgan Chase in Beijing.

item.title: French Troops Welcomed to Central African Republic
item.description: About 200 troops were deployed after African Union forces were not able to stop deadly sectarian clashes between Muslims and Christians.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Britain’s Ministry of Nudges
item.description: Inspired by American behavioral economics, the British government is finding new ways to gently prod people to pay taxes, find jobs and insulate their homes.
item.category: Office of Science and Technology Policy
Nudge: Improving Decisions About Health, Wealth, and Happiness (Book)
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The nudge team, led by David Halpern, (shown with the psychologist Alex Gyani) is using behavioral science to reach a variety of goals — like having more people insulate their attics, stop smoking during pregnancy or give to charity.

item.title: Tabu Ley Rochereau Dies; Spread the Sound of Soukous
item.description: Global influences could be heard in the music of Mr. Tabu, a Congolese singer, songwriter and politician.
item.dc:creator: By JON PARELES
item.media:description: Tabu Ley Rochereau during a concert in Central Park in 1995.

item.title: Egypt Releases 21 Female Protesters
item.description: The 14 women and 7 girls, who had participated in a street demonstration supporting Mohamed Morsi, the country’s ousted president, had been detained for over a month.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Obama Says He Can Envision Nuclear Deal With Iran
item.description: President Obama added that there was no guarantee that an accord allowing Iran to enrich nuclear material for power with enough restrictions to assure Israel would emerge during talks.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Explosion in Golan Heights Appears to Target Israeli Troops
item.description: Rather than intentional or accidental fire from the Syrian civil war, the explosion seemed to be a terrorist attack, Israeli officials said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: In Cuba’s Press, Streets and Living Rooms, Glimmers of Openness to Criticism
item.description: In recent years, Cubans close to the communist government have begun talking more openly about the economy, the political leadership and the restrictions they resent.
item.dc:creator: By VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:description: People were reflected in a window while lining up at a post office to use the Internet in Havana.

item.title: American Veteran Seized by North Korea During a Tour Returns Home
item.description: Merrill Newman was released after a month of detention in North Korea after expressing regret for his actions during the Korean War.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI and GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Merrill Newman with his wife, Lee, and son, Jeff, after arriving at the airport in San Francisco.

item.title: In Afghanistan, Hagel Presses for Pact on Security, but Is Not Meeting Karzai
item.description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel was scheduled to meet with Afghan officials to see if he could push for a breakthrough in finalizing a bilateral security agreement.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Protesters in Kabul on Saturday urged President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan to sign a security deal with the United States.

item.title: W.T.O. Reaches First Global Trade Deal
item.description: The World Trade Organization reached its first trade reform deal on Saturday, a make-or-break agreement which could add $1 trillion to the global economy.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
